title: 114_hr6141
content: The Act titled "Promoting Transparency in Trade Act" requires the publication of texts of trade agreements after each round of negotiations. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 is amended to require the publication of the United States position on a publicly available website at the conclusion of each negotiating round for proposed agreements. Additionally, the Act is amended to include the publication of positions in the Procedural Disapproval Resolution section. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 now requires the publication of United States positions on a publicly available website after each negotiating round for proposed agreements. This includes publishing positions in the Procedural Disapproval Resolution section. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 mandates the publication of US positions on a public website after each negotiation round for proposed agreements. This includes positions in the Procedural Disapproval Resolution section, with specific requirements for notification and consultation. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 requires the President to publish the United States position at the end of each negotiating round for proposed agreements. This includes specific requirements for notification and consultation. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 mandates the publication of the United States position at the conclusion of each negotiating round for proposed agreements, with specific requirements for notification and consultation. The term "United States position" refers to the full text of each proposal comprising the negotiating position of the United States. The Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act of 2015 requires the publication of the United States' position after each negotiating round for proposed agreements. This includes all new proposals offered by the United States during the negotiations. The term "negotiating round" is defined as a meeting of trade ministers from all parties involved in the negotiations. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to ensure the Chief Transparency Officer appointed by the Trade Representative does not have any conflicts of interest in ensuring transparency in trade negotiations.
